problems.title: Collatz Conjecture
problems.statementHtml:
You are doing a research paper on the famous Collatz Conjecture. In your experiment, you start off with an integer xx, and you do the following procedure kk times:

For example, starting off with 2121 and doing the procedure 55 times, you get 21→64→32→16→8→421→64→32→16→8→4.

After all kk iterations, you are left with the final value of xx. Unfortunately, you forgot the initial value. Please output any possible initial value of xx.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤4001≤t≤400). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers kk and xx (1≤k,x≤201≤k,x≤20).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print any possible initial value on a new line. It can be shown that the answer always exists.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, since 11 is odd, performing the procedure k=1k=1 times results in 1⋅3+1=41⋅3+1=4, so 11 is a valid output.

In the second test case, since 1010 is even, performing the procedure k=1k=1 times results in 102=5102=5, so 1010 is a valid output.

The third test case is explained in the statement.

problems.title: Fun Permutation
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a permutation∗∗ pp of size nn.

Your task is to find a permutation qq of size nn such that GCDGCD††(pi+qi,pi+1+qi+1)≥3(pi+qi,pi+1+qi+1)≥3 for all 1≤i<n1≤i<n. In other words, the greatest common divisor of the sum of any two adjacent positions should be at least 33.

It can be shown that this is always possible.

∗∗A permutation of length mm is an array consisting of mm distinct integers from 11 to mm in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (m=3m=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††gcd(x,y)gcd(x,y) denotes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of integers xx and yy.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n).

It is guaranteed that the given array forms a permutation.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the permutation qq on a new line. If there are multiple possible answers, you may output any.
problems.noteHtml: In the first test case, GCD(1+2,3+3)=3≥3GCD⁡(1+2,3+3)=3≥3 and GCD(3+3,2+1)=3≥3GCD⁡(3+3,2+1)=3≥3, so the output is correct.

problems.title: Maximum Even Sum
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two integers aa and bb. You are to perform the following procedure:

First, you choose an integer kk such that bb is divisible by kk. Then, you simultaneously multiply aa by kk and divide bb by kk.

Find the greatest possible even value of a+ba+b. If it is impossible to make a+ba+b even, output −1−1 instead.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers aa and bb (1≤a,b≤a⋅b≤1018)1≤a,b≤a⋅b≤1018).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the maximum even value of a+ba+b on a new line.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, it can be shown it is impossible for a+ba+b to be even.

In the second test case, the optimal kk is 22. The sum is 2+4=62+4=6.

problems.title: Replace with Occurrences
problems.statementHtml:
Given an array aa, let f(x)f(x) be the number of occurrences of xx in the array aa. For example, when a=[1,2,3,1,4]a=[1,2,3,1,4], then f(1)=2f(1)=2 and f(3)=1f(3)=1.

You have an array bb of size nn. Please determine if there is an array aa of size nn such that f(ai)=bif(ai)=bi for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n. If there is one, construct it.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤n1≤bi≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output −1−1 if there is no valid array aa.

Otherwise, print the array aa of nn integers on a new line. The elements should satisfy 1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, it can be shown that no array matches the requirement.

In the second test case, 44, 55, 66 appear 1,2,31,2,3 times respectively. Thus, the output array is correct as f(4),f(5),f(5),f(6),f(6),f(6)f(4),f(5),f(5),f(6),f(6),f(6) are 1,2,2,3,3,31,2,2,3,3,3 respectively.

problems.title: Mexification
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array aa of size nn and an integer kk. You do the following procedure kk times:

Please find the sum of elements in the array after all kk operations.

∗∗The minimum excluded (MEX) of a collection of integers d1,d2,…,dkd1,d2,…,dk is defined as the smallest non-negative integer xx which does not occur in the collection dd.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains two integers nn and kk (2≤n≤2⋅105,1≤k≤1092≤n≤2⋅105,1≤k≤109) – the number of elements in aa and the number of operations done.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the sum of elements after all kk operations on a new line.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we performed the operation on the array [0,2,1][0,2,1] three times. Let's compute the result after the first time:

  • The first element becomes MEX(2,1)=0MEX⁡(2,1)=0
  • The second element becomes MEX(0,1)=2MEX⁡(0,1)=2
  • The third element becomes MEX(0,2)=1MEX⁡(0,2)=1

So, after the first operation, [0,2,1][0,2,1] becomes [0,2,1][0,2,1] again. It can be shown that the array will not change no matter how many times we perform the operation, so the final array after three operations is still [0,2,1][0,2,1]. The sum is 0+2+1=30+2+1=3.

In the third test case, the array becomes [2,2,2,2][2,2,2,2].

problems.title: Prefix Maximum Invariance
problems.statementHtml:
Given two arrays xx and yy both of size mm, let zz be another array of size mm such that the prefix maximum at each position of zz is the same as the prefix maximum at each position of xx. Formally, max(x1,x2,…,xi)=max(z1,z2,…,zi)max⁡(x1,x2,…,xi)=max⁡(z1,z2,…,zi) should hold for all 1≤i≤m1≤i≤m. Define f(x,y)f(x,y) to be the maximum number of positions where zi=yizi=yi over all possible arrays zz.

You are given two sequences of integers aa and bb, both of size nn. Please find the value of ∑nl=1∑nr=lf([al,al+1,…,ar],[bl,bl+1,…,br])∑l=1n∑r=lnf([al,al+1,…,ar],[bl,bl+1,…,br]).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤2⋅n)(1≤ai≤2⋅n).

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤2⋅n)(1≤bi≤2⋅n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the sum of f([al,al+1,…,ar],[bl,bl+1,…,br])f([al,al+1,…,ar],[bl,bl+1,…,br]) over all pairs of (l,r)(l,r).
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the answer is the sum of the following:

  • f([5],[4])=0f([5],[4])=0, using z=[5]z=[5].
  • f([3],[2])=0f([3],[2])=0, using z=[3]z=[3].
  • f([1],[1])=1f([1],[1])=1, using z=[1]z=[1].
  • f([5,3],[4,2])=1f([5,3],[4,2])=1, using z=[5,2]z=[5,2].
  • f([3,1],[2,1])=1f([3,1],[2,1])=1, using z=[3,1]z=[3,1].
  • f([5,3,1],[4,2,1])=2f([5,3,1],[4,2,1])=2, using z=[5,2,1]z=[5,2,1].

problems.title: Cry Me a River
problems.statementHtml:
There is a directed acyclic graph with nn nodes and mm edges. Each node is initially colored blue.

Let's define the fun graph game as follows:

Since the graph is acyclic, it can be shown that the game always ends in a finite number of turns.

Note that Cry and River can win the game immediately if the starting node ss doesn't have outgoing edges, or is red respectively.

You must handle qq queries of the following kind:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, mm, qq (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105 ,1≤m,q≤2⋅1051≤m,q≤2⋅105).

The following mm lines each contain two integers uu and vv (1≤u,v≤n1≤u,v≤n), meaning that there is an edge from uu to vv.

The following qq lines each contain two integers xx and uu (1≤x≤2,1≤u≤n1≤x≤2,1≤u≤n) – denoting the type of query and the node that the query is done on.

It is guaranteed that the given graph is a directed acyclic graph. Additionally, no edge is given more than once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn, the sum of mm, and the sum of qq each do not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105 over all test cases.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each query of the second type, output YES if Cry wins. Otherwise, output NO. Each letter may be outputted in uppercase or lowercase.
problems.noteHtml:
Below shows the graph in the sample.

Initially, all nodes are blue. Thus, Cry cannot lose, and eventually the token will be moved to a node without outgoing edges.

After nodes 33 and 44 are painted red, the nodes 1,3,41,3,4 now start off as a win for River when playing optimally. If the game starts at nodes 33 and 44, River wins immediately. If the game starts at node 11, one way the game can go is as follows:

  • Cry moves the token to node 22.
  • River moves the token to node 33, which is red, so River wins.
.

It can be shown that Cry still wins with optimal play for all other nodes.

samples.output:
YES
NO
YES
NO
NO
YES
YES
YES

temporary1 800 800 900 1000 1600 1900 1700

2137A - Collatz Conjecture

Problem Credits: Proof_by_QED

Solution

The reverse of the Collatz conjecture can be written as follows:

  • Multiply xx by 22 (if 2x2x was even)
  • Subtract 11 from xx, then divide by 33 (if x−13x−13 is an integer and is odd).

In this problem, we can ignore the second type completely, because 2x2x is always an integer and is always even. We can simply print out x⋅2kx⋅2k as our answer.
